title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to animalAdoptR
text: outlines propose change animalAdoptR. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to animalAdoptR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to animalAdoptR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to animalAdoptR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("DSCI-310-2025/animalAdoptR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to animalAdoptR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to animalAdoptR
text: Please note animalAdoptR project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: animalAdoptR package provides specialized functions working animal shelter data, focus predicting adoption outcomes. vignette demonstrates use package’s main functions complete data analysis workflow.
code: library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(readr)

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: vignette, let’s create sample animal shelter data:
code: # Create sample data frame set.seed(123) n <- 100  animal_data <- data.frame(   id = 1:n,   animal_type = sample(c("Dog", "Cat", "Rabbit", "Guinea Pig", "Bird"), n, replace = TRUE,                       prob = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.1, 0.05, 0.05)),   sex = sample(c("M", "F"), n, replace = TRUE),   age = round(runif(n, 0, 15), 1),   weight_kg = round(runif(n, 1, 30), 1),   date_of_birth = as.Date("2020-01-01") - sample(1:2000, n, replace = TRUE),   intake_month = sample(formatC(1:12, width = 2, flag = "0"), n, replace = TRUE),   color = sample(c("Black", "White", "Brown", "Mixed", "Gray"), n, replace = TRUE),   adopted = sample(c("Yes", "No"), n, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.7, 0.3)) )  # Display the first few rows head(animal_data) #>   id animal_type sex  age weight_kg date_of_birth intake_month color adopted #> 1  1         Dog   M  3.6      23.8    2016-11-22           10 White     Yes #> 2  2         Cat   F 14.4       1.3    2017-11-01           03  Gray     Yes #> 3  3         Dog   F  9.0      23.6    2014-07-24           11 Black     Yes #> 4  4      Rabbit   M  7.7      22.2    2017-07-10           03 Mixed     Yes #> 5  5        Bird   F  6.0      19.3    2016-04-30           01 Mixed     Yes #> 6  6         Dog   F 13.2      14.9    2017-10-16           08 Black     Yes

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: Let’s use package’s data preparation functions clean transform data.

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: First, let’s create directories outputs:
code: ensure_dir_exists("results") ensure_dir_exists("results/figures") ensure_dir_exists("results/tables")

what: 2. Calculate Age from Date of Birth
title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: can calculate animal’s age years based date birth:
code: # Use reference date for consistent results reference_date <- as.Date("2024-01-01") animal_data$calculated_age <- calculate_age_years(animal_data$date_of_birth, reference_date)  # Compare a few records to verify calculation head(data.frame(   dob = animal_data$date_of_birth[1:5],   calc_age = animal_data$calculated_age[1:5] )) #>          dob calc_age #> 1 2016-11-22        7 #> 2 2017-11-01        6 #> 3 2014-07-24        9 #> 4 2017-07-10        6 #> 5 2016-04-30        7

what: 3. Assign Season Based on Intake Month
title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: intake month can converted season easier analysis:
code: animal_data$intake_season <- assign_season(animal_data$intake_month)  # View the distribution of intake seasons table(animal_data$intake_season) #>  #>   Fall Spring Summer Winter  #>     29     24     30     17

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: can consolidate rare animal types “” category:
code: # Group Guinea Pig and Bird into "Other" animal_data <- group_rare_categories(   animal_data,    "animal_type",    c("Guinea Pig", "Bird"),   "Other" )  # Check the distribution now table(animal_data$animal_type) #>  #>    Cat    Dog  Other Rabbit  #>     29     53      7     11

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: modeling purposes, let’s convert categorical variables factors:
code: animal_data <- convert_to_factors(   animal_data,    c("animal_type", "sex", "adopted", "intake_season") )  str(animal_data[c("animal_type", "sex", "adopted", "intake_season")]) #> 'data.frame':    100 obs. of  4 variables: #>  $ animal_type  : Factor w/ 4 levels "Cat","Dog","Other",..: 2 1 2 4 3 2 1 4 1 2 ... #>  $ sex          : Factor w/ 2 levels "F","M": 2 1 1 2 1 1 2 2 2 1 ... #>  $ adopted      : Factor w/ 2 levels "No","Yes": 2 2 2 2 2 2 1 2 2 1 ... #>  $ intake_season: Factor w/ 4 levels "Fall","Spring",..: 1 2 1 2 4 3 4 1 2 3 ...

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: Now let’s use package’s EDA functions explore data.

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: can save count tables categorical variables:
code: # Count table for animal types save_count_table(animal_data, "animal_type", "results/tables/animal_type_counts.csv")  # Count table for adoption status save_count_table(animal_data, "adopted", "results/tables/adopted_counts.csv")  # Display the adoption counts read.csv("results/tables/adopted_counts.csv") #>   adopted  n #> 1     Yes 73 #> 2      No 27

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: Let’s create bar chart showing overall adoption rates:
code: adoption_plot <- plot_adoption_distribution(animal_data) print(adoption_plot)

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: can see adoption varies animal type:
code: plot_grouped_adoption(   animal_data,   "animal_type",   "Adoption Rates by Animal Type",   "Animal Type",   "results/figures/adoption_by_type.png" )

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: age distribution can provide insights adoption preferences:
code: plot_age_distribution(animal_data, "results/figures/age_distribution.png")

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: Now, let’s build predictive model adoption outcomes.

what: 1. Split Data for Training and Testing
title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: First, let’s split data training testing sets:
code: set.seed(42) train_indices <- sample(1:nrow(animal_data), 0.7 * nrow(animal_data)) train_data <- animal_data[train_indices, ] test_data <- animal_data[-train_indices, ]  cat("Training set size:", nrow(train_data), "\n") #> Training set size: 70 cat("Test set size:", nrow(test_data), "\n") #> Test set size: 30

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: ’ll train random forest model predict adoption outcomes:
code: model <- train_rf_model(   train_data,   formula = adopted ~ animal_type + sex + calculated_age + weight_kg + intake_season,   ntree = 100,   mtry = 2,   seed = 123 )  # Print model summary print(model) #>  #> Call: #>  randomForest(formula = formula, data = d, ntree = ntree, mtry = mtry,      importance = TRUE)  #>                Type of random forest: classification #>                      Number of trees: 100 #> No. of variables tried at each split: 2 #>  #>         OOB estimate of  error rate: 47.14% #> Confusion matrix: #>     No Yes class.error #> No   1  20   0.9523810 #> Yes 13  36   0.2653061

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: Let’s evaluate well model performs test data:
code: evaluation <- evaluate_rf_model(   model,   test_data,   target_col = "adopted",   positive_level = "Yes",   negative_level = "No" )  # Display evaluation metrics evaluation$metrics #>                  Metric     Value #> Accuracy       Accuracy 0.7000000 #> Sensitivity Sensitivity 0.7916667 #> Specificity Specificity 0.3333333

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: can visualize confusion matrix better understand model performance:
code: conf_matrix_plot <- plot_confusion_matrix(   evaluation$confusion_matrix,   path_saved = "results/figures/confusion_matrix.png",   title = "Adoption Prediction Confusion Matrix" ) #> Confusion Matrix Heatmap saved in: results/figures/confusion_matrix.png

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: Finally, let’s see features important prediction:
code: importance_plot <- plot_feature_importance(   model,   path_saved = "results/figures/feature_importance.png",   title = "Importance of Features for Predicting Adoption" ) #> Feature Importance Plot saved in: results/figures/feature_importance.png

title: Getting Started with animalAdoptR
text: vignette demonstrated complete workflow using animalAdoptR analyzing animal shelter data building predictive model adoption outcomes. package provides specialized functions streamline process : Data preparation transformation Exploratory data analysis visualization Building evaluating predictive models details function, please refer function reference documentation.

what: Helper Functions for Animal Shelter Adoption Data Analysis
title: Helper Functions for Animal Shelter Adoption Data Analysis
text: animalAdoptR R package provides helper functions preprocessing, visualizing, modeling animal shelter adoption data. built part data science course project encourage code modularity, reproducibility, reusability.

title: Helper Functions for Animal Shelter Adoption Data Analysis
text: Load validate CSV datasets informative messages Preprocess group rare categories categorical variables Train evaluate random forest models Generate clean visualizations adoption rates, feature importance, confusion matrices Save plots summary tables directly file

what: Where it fits in the R package ecosystem
title: Helper Functions for Animal Shelter Adoption Data Analysis
text: animalAdoptR provides specialized streamlined workflow binary classification tasks using animal shelter data. general-purpose R packages like: tidymodels provide end--end tools model building tuning caret supports training comparing many ML algorithms …packages broader scope require configuration domain-specific workflows. contrast, animalAdoptR wraps modeling cleaning steps simple, domain-focused functions tailored adoption prediction, sensible defaults built-visualizations — making beginner-friendly students practitioners working similar projects.

title: Helper Functions for Animal Shelter Adoption Data Analysis
text: package imports following R packages: dplyr readr data wrangling ggplot2 visualization randomForest caret model training evaluation testthat testing (used development) dependencies automatically installed installing devtools::install_github(“DSCI-310-2025/animalAdoptR”) remotes::install_github(“DSCI-310-2025/animalAdoptR”). Note: dependencies automatically installed package, ’ll need load separately library() want use functions directly code.

title: Helper Functions for Animal Shelter Adoption Data Analysis
text: install development version animalAdoptR GitHub: load package:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("DSCI-310-2025/animalAdoptR") library(animalAdoptR)

title: Helper Functions for Animal Shelter Adoption Data Analysis
code: # Load and inspect data df <- load_data("data/processed/longbeach_transformed.csv")  # Train a model model <- train_rf_model(df, adopted ~ age + sex)  # Evaluate it results <- evaluate_rf_model(model, df)  # Plot confusion matrix plot_confusion_matrix(results$confusion_matrix)  # Plot feature importance plot_feature_importance(model)

title: Evaluate a classification model — evaluate_rf_model
text: model Trained model object (e.g., randomForest) test_d data frame containing test data target_col name target column. Default: "adopted" positive_level positive class level. Default: "Yes" negative_level negative class level. Default: ""

title: Evaluate a classification model — evaluate_rf_model
text: list containing: confusion_matrix (caret confusionMatrix object), metrics (dataframe performance metrics), cm_summary (confusion matrix summary)

title: Evaluate a classification model — evaluate_rf_model
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example dummy data for testing test_data <- data.frame(adopted = factor(c("Yes", "No")),                         feature1 = c(1.2, 3.4),                         feature2 = c("A", "B")) rf_model <- randomForest::randomForest(adopted ~ ., data = test_data) results <- evaluate_rf_model(rf_model, test_data)  # Access components metrics_df <- results$metrics conf_matrix <- results$confusion_matrix } # }

what: Plot confusion matrix as a heatmap Creates a heatmap visualization of a confusion matrix. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_confusion_matrix
title: Plot confusion matrix as a heatmap Creates a heatmap visualization of a confusion matrix. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_confusion_matrix
text: Plot confusion matrix heatmap Creates heatmap visualization confusion matrix. Optionally saves plot file.

title: Plot confusion matrix as a heatmap Creates a heatmap visualization of a confusion matrix. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_confusion_matrix
code: plot_confusion_matrix(   cm,   path_saved = NULL,   color_low = "#f1f1f1",   color_high = "#1f77b4",   text_color = "white",   text_size = 8,   title = "Confusion Matrix Heatmap",   width = NULL,   height = NULL )

title: Plot confusion matrix as a heatmap Creates a heatmap visualization of a confusion matrix. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_confusion_matrix
text: cm caret confusionMatrix object path_saved File path save plot. NULL, plot returned saved. color_low Color low values gradient. Default: "#f1f1f1" (light gray) color_high Color high values gradient. Default: "#1f77b4" (blue) text_color Color text labels. Default: "white" text_size Size text labels. Default: 8 title Plot title. Default: "Confusion Matrix Heatmap" width Plot width inches saving. Default: 8 height Plot height inches saving. Default: 7

title: Plot confusion matrix as a heatmap Creates a heatmap visualization of a confusion matrix. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_confusion_matrix
text: Invisibly returns ggplot object.

title: Plot confusion matrix as a heatmap Creates a heatmap visualization of a confusion matrix. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_confusion_matrix
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create dummy confusion matrix library(caret) actual <- factor(c("Yes", "No", "Yes", "No", "Yes")) predicted <- factor(c("Yes", "Yes", "No", "No", "Yes")) cm <- caret::confusionMatrix(predicted, actual)  # Plot it plot_confusion_matrix(cm) } # }

text: Plot feature importance random forest model Plots variable importance scores trained Random Forest model. Optionally saves plot file.

title: Plot feature importance from a random forest model Plots variable importance scores from a trained Random Forest model. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_feature_importance
code: plot_feature_importance(   model,   path_saved = NULL,   fill_color = "steelblue",   importance_type = 1,   title = "Feature Importance",   width = NULL,   height = NULL )

title: Plot feature importance from a random forest model Plots variable importance scores from a trained Random Forest model. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_feature_importance
text: model Trained random forest model path_saved File path save plot. NULL, plot returned saved. fill_color Color bars. Default: "steelblue" importance_type Type importance plot. Either "MeanDecreaseAccuracy" (1) "MeanDecreaseGini" (2). Default: 1 title Plot title. Default: "Feature Importance" width Plot width inches saving. Default: 10 height Plot height inches saving. Default: 8

title: Plot feature importance from a random forest model Plots variable importance scores from a trained Random Forest model. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_feature_importance
text: Invisibly returns ggplot object.

title: Plot feature importance from a random forest model Plots variable importance scores from a trained Random Forest model. Optionally saves the plot to a file. — plot_feature_importance
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example random forest model for feature importance library(randomForest) df <- data.frame(   adopted = factor(c("Yes", "No", "Yes", "Yes", "No")),   feature1 = c(2.3, 1.1, 3.4, 2.1, 0.9),   feature2 = c("A", "B", "A", "B", "A") ) model <- randomForest(adopted ~ ., data = df)  # Plot feature importance plot_feature_importance(model) } # }

title: Plot adoption distribution by group Generates a grouped bar chart showing adoption counts by a specified grouping variable. — plot_grouped_adoption
text: data data frame. group_col string specifying column group (e.g., animal_type). title string plot title. xlab string x-axis label. output_path File path save resulting plot PNG.

title: Plot adoption distribution by group Generates a grouped bar chart showing adoption counts by a specified grouping variable. — plot_grouped_adoption
text: return value. Saves plot specified file path.

title: Plot adoption distribution by group Generates a grouped bar chart showing adoption counts by a specified grouping variable. — plot_grouped_adoption
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create sample data sample_data <- data.frame(   animal_type = c("dog", "cat", "dog", "cat", "bird"),   adopted = factor(c("Yes", "No", "Yes", "No", "Yes")) ) plot_grouped_adoption(sample_data,                       "animal_type",                       "Adoption by Animal Type",                       "Animal Type",                       "results/figures/adoption_by_type.png") } # }

title: Save count table of a column Counts the occurrences of unique values in a column and saves the result as a CSV file. — save_count_table

title: Save count table of a column Counts the occurrences of unique values in a column and saves the result as a CSV file. — save_count_table

what: Train a Random Forest model — train_rf_model
title: Train a Random Forest model — train_rf_model
text: Trains Random Forest model using provided formula data. Handles standard dot notation formula. Checks missing variables ensures reproducibility via seed.

title: Train a Random Forest model — train_rf_model
code: train_rf_model(d, formula, ntree = 100, mtry = 2, seed = 123)

title: Train a Random Forest model — train_rf_model
text: d data frame containing training data formula Model formula use training (required) ntree Number trees grow. Default: 100 mtry Number variables randomly sampled split. Default: 2 seed Random seed reproducibility. Default: 123

title: Train a Random Forest model — train_rf_model
text: trained randomForest model object

title: Train a Random Forest model — train_rf_model
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example data df <- data.frame(   adopted = factor(c("Yes", "No", "Yes", "No")),   age = c(2, 5, 1, 4),   sex = factor(c("M", "F", "F", "M")) )  # Train model model <- train_rf_model(df, adopted ~ age + sex) } # }
